Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Structures and Mechanical Behavior of Nanocrystalline Phase-Containing Glass-Forming Thin Films
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Materials World Network award by the Metallic Materials and Nanostructures program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Tennessee Knoxville is to establish a fundamental understanding of the processing and fabrication of amorphous/nanocrystalline metallic thin-film coatings, and the mechanisms responsible for the resulting ductility and fatigue-resistance enhancements. This award is cofunded by the Office of Special Projects-DMR and the Office of International Science and Engineering. This collaborative experimental and theoretical project is carried out between the University of Tennessee and the team in the Republic of China (Taiwan) consisting of National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, National Taiwan Ocean University and National Cheng Kung University. This project is motivated by two novel and preliminary observations that the two teams recently discovered that: 1) metallic-glass coatings with or without the presence of nanocrystalline phases can be prepared by an annealing-induced amorphization process; and 2) these coatings on structural materials demonstrate excellent mechanical properties and fatigue resistance. In the experimental program, the Taiwan team will develop and improve the thin-film preparation method that realizes the controllable amorphization and nanocrystallization during annealing, and the USA team will focus on the deformation and fatigue behavior of these film-on-substrate systems. Advanced characterization tools, such as the high-resolution transmission-electron microscopy, will be employed to study (1) the microstructural evolution during the thin-film preparation and (2) the interaction of the strain localization and the nanocrystalline phase in the metallic-glass film during mechanical testing. From the modeling point of view, the Taiwan team will emphasize a molecular-dynamics study of the kinetic processes in the annealing-induced amorphization, while the USA team will work on the relationship between the shear-band characteristics and the mechanical behavior of the film, and the effect of the film on the fatigue behavior. The connection of these models to and comparisons with the experimental observations will lead to the basic understanding of fatigue mechanisms.

The collaborative research will advance and enhance the focused research and teaching activities on both the USA and Taiwan sides. Research projects from this joint program will be designed and used as a teaching unit for both middle- and high-school students and teachers, especially women and minority students involved in the outreach programs. These efforts are designed, not only to increase the public awareness of advanced structural materials and their scientific importance, but also to stimulate the interests of the broader public in science, engineering, and technology careers. Educational materials will be developed and disseminated through two newly-developed graduate-level classes. The present integrated research and education activities will promote the public awareness of the international-scientific collaboration.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
When coated with thin-film metallic glasses (TFMGs), the fatigue resistance of substrate materials is significantly improved, creating a vast range of practical applications. This program is investigating the processing and specific properties of these TFMGs (with or without embedded nanocrystalline phases) in order to explore further developments of the thin films. The PIs partner with team members from the National Taiwan University of Science and Technology (NTUST), National Taiwan Ocean University (NTOU), and National Cheng Kung University (NCKU), Republic of China, to form this Materials World Network Program which aims to determine the mechanisms responsible for the resulting ductility and fatigue-resistance enhancements and to further examine and develop a design for the processing and fabrication of amorphous/nanocrystalline metallic thin-film coatings on a variety of substrates.

Intellectual merit: The proposed work on the processing and properties of a novel glass-forming thin film will advance the fundamental knowledge of the glass formation, deformation, and failure mechanisms of metallic-glass materials, and, thus, will significantly promote their engineering applications. In the experimental program, the PIs have developed and improved the thin-film preparation method that realizes the controllable amorphization and nanocrystallization during annealing, and have investigated the deformation and fatigue behavior of these film-on-substrate systems. Advanced characterization tools, such as the high-resolution transmission-electron microscopy, have been employed to study (1) the microstructural evolution during the thin-film preparation and (2) the interaction of the strain localization and the nanocrystalline phase in the metallic-glass film during mechanical testing. A modeling framework has been established that relates the shear-band characteristics to the mechanical behavior of the film and the effect of the film on the fatigue behavior. These objectives and activities have been accomplished through the collaboration of investigators from the USA and Taiwan with complementary strengths. This partnership will allow both sides to join forces and accomplish goals that would otherwise be difficult to reach individually. A total of 78 papers have been published (with a large fraction in leading materials journals such as Acta Materialia), three PhD students are trained, and dozens of technical presentations have been made.

Broader impacts: The collaborative research has advanced and enhanced the focused research and teaching activities on both USA and Taiwan sides. Research activities from this project has been designed and used to involve undergraduate research. A total of six undergraduate students, including two REU students, have participated in this project, and such an experience has significantly increased their scientific interests and motivated their pursuit of technology careers. Educational materials have been disseminated in classes and broadly to the general public. The PIs have organized a serious of Bulk Metallic Glasses Symposia at the Materials, Metals, and Minerals Society conferences, which has become a critical platform for national and international researchers to exchange ideas in this area.


Last Modified: 09/24/2014
Modified by: Yanfei Gao
